I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Indonesia asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical 
assistance (TA) to ensure continuity in policy outcomes of the reform agenda for medium-term 
actions from September 2009 to June 2011. The goal is to attain deeper and more liquid capital 
markets, enhance market supervision, and improve regulatory resources and capacity. The 
ultimate aims are to improve overall governance standards for capital markets and provide 
greater  investor  protection.  These  activities  are  critical  to  promote  resilience,  growth,  and 
sustainability  of  capital  markets;  and  make  the  Indonesian  capital  market  more  efficient, 
competitive, financially sound, and responsive to global trends.1  
 
2.   The Indonesia country strategy and program for 2006–2009 identifies deepening of the 
financial sector to promote enhanced financial sector resilience as one of five key areas of ADB 
interventions.2 The ADB Capital Market Development Program Cluster (CMDPC)3 evolves from 
the government’s medium-term development plan (2004–2009) to support the government’s 
financial sector reform agenda in line with the country strategy and program, and with a principal 
focus on development of capital markets. A policy reform program (1 January 2006 to October 
2010), under the CMDPC, comprises two subprograms: subprogram 1 from January 2006 to 
September 2007 and subprogram 2 from October 2007 to August 2009.4 The government 
recognizes that the reform program will need to extend beyond the two subprograms. In line 
with this, a post-program partnership framework for follow-up policy actions for September 
2009–June 2011 was developed in consultation with various agencies. The government and 
financial industry recognize the importance of this capacity-building initiative and discussions 
have been under way for some time among government agencies, industry associations, and 
local universities. The CMDPC aims to support these efforts and lend momentum via the TA, 
which will help meet immediate needs and allow for a systematic approach to medium- and 
longer-term efforts. This report reflects the findings of the mission and understandings reached 
with the government on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, 
financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The TA design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Financial sector reforms are crucial to raising Indonesia’s growth rate and enhancing the 
economy’s  resilience. Indonesia’s capital markets are relatively smaller and the secondary 
markets less liquid than those of most other Southeast Asian economies. With equity market 
capitalization at 36% of gross domestic product (GDP) as of October 2009, Indonesia has the 
smallest market; Hong Kong, China has the largest, followed by Singapore, Republic of Korea, 
Malaysia, People's Republic of China, Philippines, and Thailand. Even for debt markets, based 
on total bonds outstanding against GDP in 2008, Indonesia’s ratio of 13.6% places it among the 
smaller markets in the region. Effective implementation of medium-term action plans relies on 
adequate financial resources and continued support of key agencies such as the capital market 
and nonbank financial institutions regulator, Bapepam-LK, until greater institutional capacity and 
resources are attained. Against the backdrop of clearly defined sector goals and strategies, and 
a strong commitment to reform as evidenced by progress achieved during last 3 years, the TA

will help meet immediate needs and allow for a systematic approach to medium- and longer-
term  efforts.  The  TA  will  complement  change  management  assistance  being  provided  by 
Australian Agency for International Development. To attain this goal, 11 main issues were 
identified for support under the TA.  
 
4.  Support  implementation  of  the  capital  market  master  plan  (2010–2014).  TA 
attached to subprogram 1 of the CMDPC (footnote 3) is assisting Bapepam-LK to develop a 
capital market master plan for 2010–2014. The master plan will provide a clear statement of the 
strategic philosophy underpinning development efforts in Indonesia's capital markets for the 
next 5 years, and outline a plan of action incorporating specific recommendations for developing 
the capital market. Implementation of these recommendations will take into account the optimal 
sequencing for orderly progression to meet the challenges of increasing globalization.  
 
5.  Support benchmarking for the regulatory framework to harmonize standards and 
regional  cooperation.  Support  is  required  to  assess  the  regulatory  framework  for  areas 
covered by Bapepam-LK vis-à-vis other member countries of the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN), as well as benchmarking with international best practices to promote 
regional cooperation and harmonization of standards. Based on standards of the International 
Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), ASEAN regulators have developed a single 
set  of  common  disclosure  standards  for  cross-border  issuances,  known  as  the  ASEAN 
Standards, together with additional requirements prescribed by each jurisdiction, known as the 
Plus Standards. The overall scheme is envisaged to bring greater efficiency and cost-saving for 
issuers undertaking cross-border offerings once the ASEAN standards are accepted by each 
country.  Afterward,  other  aspects  of  Indonesia's  regulatory  framework  will  need  to  be 
benchmarked to identify areas where complementary measures are needed to give confidence 
to regulators in other countries. Bilateral agreements with Indonesia on common standards can 
then be made on adequate enforcement and supervisory capabilities in Bapepam-LK 
 
6.  Support strengthening of Bapepam-LK's investigative and enforcement capacity. 
This will be accomplished by providing necessary training programs and secondments with 
relevant enforcement and/or regulatory authorities: While considerable progress has been made 
in strengthening the anti-money-laundering regime for banking, the nonbank financial subsector  
currently lags in comparison, in terms of the effectiveness of regulations and supervision, as 
well as the capacity of institutions to comply with the law. To reduce the risk of nonbank 
financial institutions being used as conduits for money laundering, regulations, supervision 
(capacity, enforcement powers, and sanctions), and capacity for compliance will need to be 
strengthened to achieve parity with the banking system.  
 
7.  Support the development and implementation of an investor protection fund. This 
would  include  regulation  of  investor  protection  funds  for  the  securities  market  and  credit 
guarantees. Indonesia does not have an investor protection fund to protect investors in the 
event of broker default. The rules require securities firms to take out insurance to cover this 
eventuality, but such insurance is not available and the rule has not been enforced. This 
exposes investors to significant risk and is likely to deter investors of all sizes from participating 
in the market. Such funds are typically built up by contributions from brokers The CMDPC 
requires Bapepam-LK to compensate investors in registered investment companies for financial 
loss they may suffer due to reasons prescribed by the regulator other than market decline in the 
investment portfolio of the investment company.  
 
8.  Develop a structured and comprehensive human resource capacity program for 
Bapepam-LK. Bapepam-LK will require support over the medium term for it to become an

3 
effective regulator. Governance of regulatory agencies and market institutions requires staff with 
graduate education in actuarial science and finance, and experience in regulatory practices and 
market surveillance in developed markets. Acquiring these skills is a precondition for success, 
but will be a major challenge, requiring the government to commit adequate resources over the 
medium and long term if technical and regulatory excellence is to be achieved.  
 
9.  Support development of a comprehensive database and user-friendly website. The 
capital market and nonbank financial subsector will benefit greatly from the development of a 
structured  and  comprehensive  database  and  user-friendly  website  to  provide  consolidated 
capital  market  and  nonbank  financial  institution  information  in  appropriate  presentations 
available  in  both  Bahasa  Indonesia  and  English.  Only  through  the  steady  flow  of  timely, 
comprehensive, and accurate information can people make sound investment decisions. The 
website  should  include  information  on  insurance  and  capital  market  products  and  related 
subjects.  
 
10.  Establish a capital markets institute. Bapepam-LK is studying several options to serve 
the  research  needs  of  capital  markets  and  the  contractual  savings  industries,  including 
developing  and  adopting  a  plan  of  collaboration  with  universities  in  Indonesia.  Resource 
capacity and skills of the entire capital markets need to be enhanced to operate in a more 
competitive environment, hence the need for a centralized capital market training institute to 
focus  on  capacity  building  for  all  capital  market  sectors.  An  important  milestone  is  the 
memorandum of understanding under subprogram 2 of the CMDPC in 2009 to initiate the 
capital markets institute cooperatively by Indonesian Stock Exchange, PT Kliring Penjaminan 
Efek  Indonesia  (Indonesian  Clearing  and  Guarantee  Corporation),  Kustodian  Sentral  Efek 
Indonesia (Indonesian Central Securities Depository), University of Indonesia, and Bapepam-LK 
to provide a focus for undergraduate, graduate, and professional training to develop capital 
markets.  
 
11.  Support reforms likely to be required following reviews under the Financial Sector 
Assessment Program. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are conducting 
the program to provide a comprehensive and up-to-date diagnosis of Indonesia's finance sector 
vulnerabilities. This is expected to complete by mid 2010. The program seeks to determine how 
key  sources  of  risk  are  being  managed;  and  to  help  prioritize  policy  responses.  Detailed 
assessments of relevant financial sector standards and codes are also being undertaken.  
 
12.  Support  development  of  a  comprehensive  compliance  framework  for  capital 
markets to enhance investor protection. As early as 1998, IOSCO required implementation 
of an effective compliance program as one of the 30 principles of securities regulation. Likewise, 
the  Bank  for  International  Settlement  developed  a  set  of  principles  to  govern  compliance 
requirements  for  banking  institutions.  It  helps  promote  a  business  culture  that  values  and 
promotes not only compliance in form but also in substance, coupled with a high ethical and 
investor protection standard. This is viewed as a building block to good governance. Support is 
required  for  Bapepam-LK  to  develop  a  comprehensive  compliance  framework  for  capital 
markets  and  help  IDX  develop  detailed  rules  on  compliance  functions  for  stock-brokering 
companies.  
 
13.  Support the introduction of new products, such as mortgage credit insurance and 
other risk management products. With the need to increase the supply of liquid and highly 
rated assets as a major priority, new products must be introduced. Recently introduced financial 
products include (i) exchange-traded funds, (ii) asset-backed securities (iii) single-stock futures, 
and (iv) stock lending and borrowing. Introduction of risk management products by Bapepam-LK

4 
such as interest rate and bond futures, as well as mortgage credit insurance would need 
support. Bapapem-LK wishes to develop an efficient mortgage insurance system to protect 
lenders and investors against loss by reason of borrower default in situations where the home 
value (net of foreclosure-related costs) is insufficient to fully repay the mortgage obligation. 
Financial institutions usually grant housing loans based solely on collateral of borrowers, within 
the loan-to-value limit of each bank. Mortgage credit insurance will facilitate the development of 
the housing finance industry and enhance credit for housing.  
 
14.  Strengthen and consolidate the insurance industry. Historically, capital requirements 
for insurance companies have been lax and licensing requirements loose. The industry was 
sheltered from international competition, and state involvement was significant. The Indonesian 
insurance industry is small, but highly fragmented with 51 life insurance companies, 97 general 
insurance companies, and 4 reinsurance companies. The industry is heavily concentrated, with 
the top 5 general insurance companies accounting for 51% of general insurance assets and the 
top 5 life insurance companies accounting for 55% of life insurance assets. Bapepam-LK issued 
rules  in  2008  requiring  minimum  equity  for  insurance  companies  to  be  increased  from  
Rp40 billion to Rp100 billion and for reinsurance companies from Rp100 billion to Rp200 billion 
over a transition period from 2010 to 2014.  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the TA will be greater financial sector diversification and resilience. The 
outcome will be increased contribution by the capital market to domestic financing.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
16.  The TA, associated with the CMDPC, will address immediate and short-term capacity-
building needs and complement the change management assistance provided by Australian 
Agency for International Development. The TA will support development of a deeper and more 
resilient  capital  market  and  enhanced  supervision  with  improved  regulatory  resources  and 
capacity. Key areas of focus under the TA include support for:  
 
(i)  curricula for training programs and standards for certification for professionals in 
capital market-related fields; 
(ii)  strengthened capacity of Bapepam-LK; 
(iii)  recommendations  and  implementation  of  key  reforms  and  regulations  in  the 
financial sector; and 
(iv)  technical  advice  for  the  development  of  new  capital  market  products, 
strengthened market supervision, and regulatory capacity with ultimate aims to 
improve overall governance standards of capital markets and investor protection.  
 
17.  Key outputs and related activities include: (i) implementation of the capital market master 
plan (2010–2014); (ii) benchmarking of a regulatory framework for harmonizing standards and 
regional  cooperation;  (iii)  strengthening  of  Bapepam-LK's  investigative  and  enforcement 
capacity;  (iv)  regulatory  reforms  that  are  likely  to  be  required  following  reviews  under  the 
Financial  Sector  Assessment  Program;  (v)  development  and  establishment  of  an  investor 
protection fund for the securities market; (vi) development of a structured and comprehensive 
human resource capacity program for Bapepam-LK; (vii) development of a comprehensive 
capital markets database and website for public information services and the promotion of

5 
market  transparency;  (viii)  establishment  of  a  capital  markets  institute  for  capital  markets;  
(ix) development of a comprehensive compliance framework for capital markets to enhance 
investor protection; (x) introduction of new products, such as mortgage credit insurance; and  
(xi) strengthening and consolidation of the insurance Industry. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $1,900,000  equivalent,  of  which  ADB  will  provide 
$1,500,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the ADB Technical Assistance 
Special Fund (TASF—other sources). The government will provide the remaining $400,000 
equivalent by providing counterpart staff and other support facilities. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  Bapepam-LK  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  It  will  provide  office  space, 
counterpart staff, and other services to the consultants. It will closely coordinate with other 
stakeholders involved in TA implementation. A capital markets capacity-building committee 
comprising representatives from Bapepam-LK will be established to provide guidance on the 
allocation and use of training-related funds under the TA. The TA is expected to commence in 
March 2010 and be completed by December 2011.  
 
20.  A  combination  of  consulting  firms  and  individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time), based on requirements to be identified during CMDPC implementation and the follow-up 
policy measures under the post-program monitoring framework. The activities (para. 17) will not 
be undertaken simultaneously, rather their implementation will depend on the pace of reforms 
undertaken over the next 2 years. The TA proposes a degree of flexibility in the methodology of 
consultant engagement, either through a firm or individuals. For implementation of the master 
plan,  a  minimum  of  10  person-months  of  international  consulting  and  6  person-months  of 
national consulting will be engaged through a firm selected using quality-based selection. This 
method  is  used  as  the  assignments  entail  recommending  and  drafting  key  reforms  and 
regulations in the financial sector; inadequacies will result in high costs for both the sector and 
the economy. Short-listed firms will submit simplified technical proposals. The TA will include  
36.5 person-months of international consulting and 20 months of national consulting focusing on 
technical advice concerning the development of new capital market products, enhancement of 
market supervision, and improvement of regulatory resources and capacity. The ultimate aims 
are to improve the overall governance standards for capital markets and accord greater investor 
protection.  All  consultants  will  submit  an  inception  report  detailing  a  draft  work  plan  and 
schedule within 1 week of fielding, and provide concise regular updates to Bapepam-LK and 
ADB outlining progress and identifying implementation issues. Where appropriate, midterm, 
draft final, and final reports will be required to be submitted according to a schedule agreed to 
with Bapepam-LK and ADB. All services, equipment, and material to support implementation of 
the TA will be procured by direct purchase in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Equipment will include computer hardware and software 
related to development and management of the capital markets database and website and 
coordination requirements among the concerned regulatory agencies. All equipment procured 
under the TA will be handed over to concerned counterpart agencies upon TA completion.

6 
Bapepam-LK will disseminate relevant TA outputs though its website. Disbursements under the 
TA will be made in accordance with the ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.5  
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for Strengthening Indonesia's Capital Market, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  11
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Help with regulatory issues arising from the self-assessment of the International 
Organization  of  Securities  Commissions  and  Financial  Sector  Assessment  Program 
(FSAP): international expert in IOSCO standards (1.5 person-months). The expert will have 
performed  FSAP  assessments,  and  have  more  than  10  years  experience  in  international 
benchmarking and international best practices and standards. 
 
2.    The consultant will conduct a comprehensive review of the requirements of the FSAP, 
and provide suggestions on any regulatory issues to be addressed prior to actual assessment. 
The tasks will be undertaken over 1.5 months during October–November 2010 (depending on 
the date of receipt of the assessment report). 
   
3.  Support implementation of the capital market master plan (2010–2014): a maximum 
of 10 person-months of international consulting and 5 person-months of national consulting is 
envisaged). A consulting firm is likely to be engaged.  
 
4.  The consultants will support implementation of a capital market master plan for 2010–
2014  starting  from  2010.  The  TA  resources  required  will  be  determined  based  on  the 
implementation milestones to be developed by the end of 2009.  
 
5.  Improve market surveillance and investor protection, and assess the regulatory 
framework:  international  financial  sector  regulatory  expert  (2  person-months)  and  national 
financial sector expert (2 person-months). 
 
6.  The international expert will have a good understanding of international best practices 
and prudential requirements for financial and capital markets, understand accounting issues, 
and have been deeply involved in international benchmarking exercises. The expert should 
have more than 10 years experience in markets and regulation. The national expert will have a 
good knowledge of domestic laws and regulatory requirements to provide a national perspective 
in support of the international expert's work. 
 
7.  The consultants’ responsibilities will include the following (to be completed by the end of 
first quarter of 2010): 
 
(i)   Study  the  various  domestic  standards  and  best  practices  as  practiced  by 
Bapepam-LK and relevant capital market authorities. 
(ii)   Compare best practices and prudential standards applicable to national capital 
market sectors with that of ASEAN Plus standards and standards practiced by 
countries in this region. Complete gap assessments for Indonesia. 
(iii)   Highlight current gaps and areas for improvement. 
  (iv)   Actively work with Bapepam-LK and make necessary recommendations including 
mode of implementation and timeline for consideration of Bapepam-LK. 
     
8.  Support strengthening of Bapepam-LK's investigative and enforcement capacity: 
international capital market regulatory and enforcement expert (2 person-months) 
(i)   Resources from key strategic regulator with more than 10 years experience in 
investigation of securities offences and Anti-Money Laundering Activities. 
(ii)   A 5-day training on forensic investigation requires a competent resource person 
from any of the top four accounting firms.

12         Appendix 3   
9.  The expert will provide 
(i)  training in forensic investigation, 
(ii)  training in investigative skills and techniques for AMLA-related offences, 
(iii)  secondment of Bapepam-LK staff with the PPATK in Indonesia, 
(iv)  invitations for resources people from international regulatory bodies to conduct 
in-house training on investigation and prosecution skills, and 
(v)  case studies and investigative tool kits for self learning. 
   
10.  Develop  an  implementation  plan  to  regulate  investor  protection  funds  for  the 
securities market and credit guarantee: international securities market regulatory expert (2 
person-months) and one national securities market legal expert (2 person-months).  
 
11.  The international expert will have at least 10 years direct experience in developing 
regulatory frameworks, drafting laws and rules, and setting up and implementing an investor 
protection fund. The national expert will have a legal background with a good understanding of 
capital markets and investor guarantee fund. 
 
12.  The consultants will undertake the following (to be completed by second quarter of 
2010): 
 
(i)  Assist Bapepam-LK in developing the framework for investor protection including 
benchmarking exercise with countries in this region, cost–benefit analysis, and 
industry engagement; and recommend appropriate model. 
(ii)  Help Bapepam-LK draft the legal reform work for the recommended framework 
for implementation purposes. 
(iii)  Help Indonesian Stock Exchange formulate the exchange's rules for an investor 
protection fund applicable to members. 
(iv)  Provide training to staff of Bapepam-LK and IDX. 
(v)  Assist Bapepam-LK and IDX in conducting awareness seminars and training to 
the industry. 
 
13.  Develop  a  structured  and  comprehensive  human  resource  capacity  building 
program for Bapepam-LK: international senior human resource specialist (6 person-months) 
and national human resource expert (6 person-months). The international specialist will have 
more than 15 years experience in human resources and capacity building using the latest 
human resource techniques, and have worked for large institutions in related human resource 
capacity building and training. The national consultant will have the required experience to 
support the international expert.  
 
14.  The consultants’ scope of work includes the following: 
 
(i)  Assist  Bapepam-LK  in  conducting  gap  assessments  and  recommend  a 
comprehensive and structured human resource plan for the entire staff looking 
into talent management, staff career development, succession planning, staff 
rotation program, training and development, job performance evaluation, and 
personalized individual staff career program. 
(ii)  Provide coaching and mentoring program for staff in talent management pool. 
(iii)  Provide  human  resource  plan  for  nonperformers  including  counseling  and 
actions. 
(iv)  Provide feedback to management and regular review.

Appendix 3  13
15.  Develop  a  comprehensive  database  and  user-friendly  website  to  provide 
consolidated  information  on  capital  markets  and  nonbank  financial  institutions: 
international  database  and  information  technology  expert  (3  person-months)  and  national 
website  designer  (3  person-months).  The  international  consultant  should  have  a  finance 
industry  background  with  more  than  10  years  experience  in  developing  comprehensive 
databases  or  heading  major  database  projects.  The  national  consultant  will  support  the 
information technology expert. 
 
16.  The consultants will undertake the following to be completed by the third quarter of 2010:  
 
(i)  Develop a website and system design for a capital market database. 
(ii)  Identify industrywide basis input, data, statistics, and resources for a centralized 
capital markets database, including standard template for industry reporting and 
the most efficient mode of transmitting information and data to be inputted in the 
database. 
(iii)  Undertake regulatory and market research, interfacing with data sources and 
updates. 
(iv)  Develop dedicated resources. 
(v)  Obtain regular feedback from users. 
 
17.  Establish a capital markets institute for capital markets: international institutional 
development expert (4 person-months). The consultant will have more than 20 years experience 
in capacity building, training and development, research or academia; or direct experience 
running a capital market institute or in related field; and have good understanding of capital 
markets and financial sectors. The consultant will be required on an intermittent basis. 
 
18.  The consultant will support the development and establishment of a capital markets 
institute and related training and capacity development initiatives. This is an ongoing project, 
support is needed at least for the first 12 months of formation of the institute, 2010–2012. The 
scope of work includes recommending the blueprint, strategic direction, and action plans for the 
institute. This includes 
 
(i)  visiting fellow program for the University of Indonesia; 
(ii)  research and development program for capital markets; 
(iii)  professional development program; 
(iv)  doctoral research program with focus on the Indonesian capital market; 
(v)  curriculum development; 
(vi)  collaborative  programs  with  universities  abroad,  research  centers,  and 
corporations; and 
(vii)  work to centralize examination activities for licensed persons for capital market 
sectors. 
   
19.  Develop a comprehensive compliance framework for capital markets to enhance 
investor protection and support capacity building: international capital market regulatory 
and compliance expert (2 person-months). The consultant will have more than 10 years direct 
experience in regional compliance, be knowledgeable of banking and capital markets, and 
preferably have a legal background.  
 
20.  The  consultant  will  support  Bapepam-LK  develop  a  comprehensive  compliance 
framework for the capital markets and assist IDX in developing detail rules on compliance

14         Appendix 3   
functions for stock-brokering companies. The work is to be completed over 3 months by the 
second quarter of 2010. Specifics tasks to be undertaken include the following: 
 
(i)  Perform  gap  assessment  in  the  current  practice  of  market  intermediaries  in 
regard to compliance functions and undertake a benchmarking exercise.  
(ii)  Identify what support could be obtained directly, such as assistance from other 
jurisdictions  that  have  implemented  compliance  functions,  and  advise  on 
methods to optimize this support in a timely and effective manner. 
(iii)  Develop a comprehensive framework on compliance functions and detail rules 
for Bapepam-LK, IDX, and market intermediaries. 
(iv)  Develop modules for examinations for compliance officers. 
(v)  Train staff of Bapepam-LK, IDX, and market intermediaries on the compliance 
program and implementation. 
   
21.  New products: mortgage credit insurance and other risk management products: 
international mortgage credit insurance expert (2 person-months). The expert will have more 
than 5 years working experience in the area of mortgage insurance, have drafted regulatory 
frameworks for mortgage insurance, and preferably have a legal background. The work will be 
completed by March 2010. The consultant will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Conduct a feasibility study (over 1 month) on the suitability and readiness of the 
Indonesian  capital  market  to  introduce  mortgage  insurance.  This  includes 
performing a benchmarking exercise on practices of other countries that have 
introduced mortgage insurance in this region, conduct cost–benefit analysis of 
mortgage insurance in Indonesia, and make appropriate recommendation on 
implementing mortgage insurance to PT SMF. Provide the necessary training to 
PT SMF staff. 
(ii)  Draft the regulatory framework for mortgage insurance for the Indonesian capital 
market for Bapepam-LK. Provide training to Bapepam-LK staff. 
 
22.   Support insurance industry consolidation: international insurance industry expert (2 
person-months) and national insurance industry expert (2 person-months). The international 
expert preferably will have a good understanding of the insurance industry, relevant direct 
experience in providing advice and negotiating with insurance companies on mergers and 
acquisitions, have a good understanding of how the domestic insurance sector operates in 
Indonesia,  and  have  more  than  10  years  experience  in  corporate  finance.  The  national 
consultant will have a background of at least 5 years of corporate finance experience and a 
good understanding of the local insurance industry.  
 
23.  The consultants will provide support for insurance industry consolidation in Indonesia by 
assisting smaller insurance firms to solicit merger partners that can help them meet the higher 
capital  requirements  and  strengthen  the  insurance  industry.  The  consultants’  work,  to  be 
completed by the second quarter of 2010, includes the following: 
 
(i)    Actively  engage  with  self  regulatory  organizations  on  the  status  of  small 
insurance companies that are not likely to be able to meet the higher and/or new 
capital requirements, and provide guidance and advice to SROs. 
(ii)   Through SROs, have active engagement and brainstorming sessions with small 
insurance companies on how to approach suitable merger partners and arrange 
for meetings and discussions.

Appendix 3  15
(iii)   Provide advice and guidance to small insurance companies (affected companies) 
on  merger  issues,  pricing,  suitability  of  partners,  negotiations,  and  how  to 
maximize opportunities. 
(iv)  Provide training or seminars, if necessary. 
 (v)  Highlight  key  regulatory  issues  to  Bapepam-LK  and  make  specific 
recommendations.
